areaDesc.2: Known as Troup Street Extension. Land is level. About 16 houses in the area
areaDesc.3: Proximity to schools and churches. Zoned and restricted for residential purposes. Streets 100% paved.
areaDesc.4: Distance from parks and playgrounds. Lack of transportation facilities. Adjoins Camp Pendleton (camp reserved for disabled war veterans and their families). Portion outside of the city limits subject to garbage collection fee.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Portion of Summerville. Western part of area level; while eastern portion slopes off steeply. About 100 houses in this area.
areaDesc.3: Zoned and restricted for single-family dwellings. Proximity to community business center. About 90% of the streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Practically none.
areaDesc.13: Stable for next 5 years, then slowly downward with the age of properties.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Portion of Monte Sano; land is level.
areaDesc.3: Practically none.
areaDesc.4: Absence of parks, playgrounds, schools, churches, and community business centers. Zoned for multiple dwellings. 25% of streets paved. Infiltration of lower grade population. Encroachment of industrial property. Racial clash of occupants mixture of racial classes.

5.a: Skilled mechanics, clerical workers and laborers

areaDesc.14: Negroes are on both sides of Kind Street and Turknett Spring Road; also on both sides of Central Avenue (McKinley Drive) between Russell Street and Hickman Road. (a) Individual lenders only.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Land is level and flat
areaDesc.3: Proximity to parks, playgrounds, schools, churches and community business center; within walking distance of city. Bus and street car transportation facilities. 50% of the streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Zoned for multiple dwellings and commercial purposes. Infiltration of lower class white. Noises and heavy traffic. Encroachment of apartments, commercial and industrial property. Heavily burdened tax district.

5.a: Clerical workers, skilled mechanics and laborers

areaDesc.14: (a) Local individual lenders only.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Known as Lakemont. Rolling. About 20 houses in area.
areaDesc.3: Topography of land and abundance of shade trees. Zoned for residential purposes (outside of city); 100% of streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Lack of transportation facilities; unattractive approach to area (through mill district). Distance from schools, churches, business centers. No gas; many septic tanks. Proximity to public bathing beach and park. Garbage collection fee.

5.a: Executives, business men and clerical workers

areaDesc.14: (a) Development of this subdivision began about 1936, but up to 1934 only 4 houses had been built in the area, and at present there are about 20 houses in the area.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Known as Blanchard Tract; contains about 25 houses. Land is high and level.
areaDesc.3: Adjoins Forrest Hills, Forrest Hills Hotel and Golf Course. Scenic features; about 350 ft. above city. Adequate bus transportation to within 3 blocks of the area. Zoned and restricted for moderate priced residential property.
areaDesc.4: Distance from schools, churches, business center, parks and playgrounds. About 33 1/3% of the streets paved. Garbage collection fee. Adjoins Municipal Airport and American Legion headquarters club.
areaDesc.14: There is a tendency for people to occupy this area who cannot afford expensive homes, but who want to be near the exclusive Forrest Hills section (A-1).

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Land is perfectly level and flat.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to schools, churches and main business section of city. Within walking distance of heart of city. 100% of streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Zoned for commercial purposes. Heavy traffic conditions. Infiltration of lower grade population. Encroachment of commercial and industrial properties. Heavy tax burden on property. Increasing number of tourist homes and boarding houses. Advanced age of properties.
areaDesc.14: (a) By individual lenders only

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Land is rolling
areaDesc.3: Low taxation. Scenic features.
areaDesc.4: Lack of zoning or restrictions. Distance from playgrounds, parks, and community business center. D-8 considerable distance from bus line, which runs along Georgia Avenue. No paved streets. Inadequate fire protection. Septic tanks. No schools. Age and repair condition of properties.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Land is rolling
areaDesc.3: Low taxation. Scenic features.
areaDesc.4: Lack of zoning or restrictions. Distance from playgrounds, parks, and community business center. D-8 considerable distance from bus line, which runs along Georgia Avenue. No paved streets. Inadequate fire protection. Septic tanks. No schools. Age and repair condition of properties.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: D-10 is known as Dublin; D-11 is known as Terry; land in all 3 areas is flat and level.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to schools, churches, and community business centers. D-9 and 10 are within walking distance of center of the city; while D-11 has street car facilities. 50% of the streets paved in D-9 and 10.
areaDesc.4: Zoned for commercial and industrial purposes. About 15% of the streets paved in D-11. Encroachment by commercial and industrial property affects all 3 areas. D-11 affected by obnoxious odors; also heavy traffic along U.S. Highway #1. D-9 affected by heavy traffic. All 3 areas subject to fire hazards. Heavily burdened tax tax districts. Difficulty of collections; population shift within areas to avoid rent payments. Moderate amount vandalism. Open sewers in southern edge of D-11.*

5.f: Many: decreasing, being cut off relief rolls by W.P.A.

d.1: D-9 - Yes; D-10 - Yes; D-11 - Yes

6.a: D-9: Lg 2 sty doubles; D-10,11: 1 sty 3-4 rm singles

areaDesc.14: *No city sewerage; (a) Only individual lenders and then only on a heavily restricted basis. About 25% of values.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: D-1 known as Harrisburg, land is level. Portion of D-6 known as Bridwell's Bottom, land is level.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to park, playgrounds, community business center, schools, and churches. Good bus and street car transportation facilities.
areaDesc.4: Zoned for industrial and commercial. 10% of the streets paved. Property adjoining textile mills subjected to objectionable noises. Heavy traffic conditions on Broad Street and Walton Way are hazardous. Encroachment of commercial and industrial properties. Difficulty of rental collections. Shifting of tenants from one property to another to avoid payment of rent.

5.a: Mill workers and few skilled mechanics

areaDesc.14: Principal negro properties are confined to small area west of the industrial canal just off Broad Street, along Hicks Street, and on east side of Ellis Street, just north of Milledge Road - all in D-1; in D-6 they occupy both sides of Reynolds and Jones Streets and also southern portion of area along canal. (a) Individual lenders are only type of lender that will make loans in these areas.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Known as Walton Way Extension and Forrest Hills. High rolling land (about 362 ft. about city). About 100 houses in area.
areaDesc.3: Highly restricted and zoned for better class residential. Bus transportation to Forrest Hills. About 7 blocks to community business center, churches, and schools. Area well landscaped and commands beautiful view. Proximity to Forrest Hills Hotel ($800,000) and Forrest Hills Golf Course.
areaDesc.4: No parks or playgrounds in this area. About 75% of the streets paved. Few shade trees. Many septic tanks. Forrest Hills portion subject to garbage collection fee, since it is outside the city limits.
areaDesc.14: (a) Activity is Forrest Hills portion of this area in 1928-1929 was confined to vacant lot sales, while in the remaining portion of the area, houses were closely held - hence no sales.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Known as Hampton Terrace. Land is high and sloping. About 18 houses in the area.
areaDesc.3: Scenic features. Adequate bus transportation facilities. Proximity to schools, churches, and business center. Zoned and restricted for moderate-priced residential property. Low taxation.
areaDesc.4: Lack of shade trees. About 20% of the streets are paved. Heavy traffic conditions along Georgia Avenue (U.S. Highway #25). Tendency toward soil erosion because of presence of clay soil and steep decline of the terrain.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Portion of Summerville; land is high and fairly level. About 150 to 200 houses in the area.
areaDesc.3: Parks and recreation center. Good transportation facilities (bus). Proximity to schools, churches, and community business center. Zoned and restricted for single family dwellings. 66 2/3% of the streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Practically none
areaDesc.14: A cheaper type of residence than in the remainder of the area, is located along Helen Street.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Portion of Summerville. Land is high and level. About 85 houses in this area.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to parks, recreational center, and schools. Good bus transportation facilities. Zoned and restricted for single-family dwellings.
areaDesc.4: Negro community adjoining this area to the north. About 30% of the streets paved.

6.b: 33 1/3% Brick veneer; 33 1/3% Frame; 33 1/3% Stucco on frame

areaDesc.14: This area adjoins D-12, but negro property is separated from white property by strip of vacant lots between the two sections.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Known as Summerville Terrace. Land is sloping eastward. About 200 houses in this area.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to best public high and grammar schools; proximity to parks and recreational centers. Zoned for single and double-family dwellings; deed restrictions as to race and residential use. About 66 2/3% of the streets paved. Good transportation facilities (bus and street car).
areaDesc.4: Distance from churches and proximity to negro property on southern end of area.
areaDesc.14: This area abutts D-2, the negro property in which fronts on McDowell Alley and is separated from the white property by the alley and back yards of said white property.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Known as Central Avenue Subdivision. Land is flat and level. About 60 houses in the area.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to good grammar and high schools. Good transportation facilities (street cars). Zoned for one and two-family dwellings; restricted as to racial and residential use.
areaDesc.4: About 25% of the streets paved.

5.a: Skilled mechanics, clerical and railroad workers

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Known as Monte Sano. Land is high, sloping and sandy.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to public grade school , street car facilities on Central Avenue (also known as McKinley Drive and Oglethorpe Drive). Zoned for single-family dwellings. 90% of the streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Property adjoining Veteran's Hospital (Lenwood Reservation), is adversely affected by hospital.

5.a: Mixture: Executives, business men and clerical workers

areaDesc.14: The southern portion of Tuxado Park (Ohio and Pennsylvania Avenue) contains a much cheaper grade of property than that in the remainder of the area; should be classified as "almost D grade property".

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Known as portion of Summerville. Land is high, sloping and sandy.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to parks, playgrounds, community business center, churches and schools. Good transportation facilities (street car). Zoned for single-family dwellings. 85% of streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Practically none.

5.a: Mixture: Executives, business men and clerical workers

areaDesc.14: A group of cheap white and negro houses, which should be classified as "D" grade property, is located on both sides of McDowell Street from Monte Sano Avenue almost to Heath Street, and on both sides of East Avenue.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Land is sloping.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to parks, playgrounds, schools, and community business center. Bus transportation facilities. Zoned for one and two-family residences.
areaDesc.4: 5% of streets paved. Distance from churches. Nuisance effect (flies, etc.) of Bon Air Hotel stables.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Land is level
areaDesc.3: Proximity to schools and community business center. Zoned for one and two-family residences. Good bus and street car transportation facilities.
areaDesc.4: Distance to parks, playgrounds and churches. 10% of the streets paved.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Known as Pinch Gut. Land is level; below levee level, but not below river level.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to grammar schools and churches; community business centers as well as main business section of the city. Bus and street car transportation. 95% of the streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Absence of parks and playgrounds. Distance to high schools. Zoned for multiple family dwellings. Infiltration of lower grade white residents. Encroachment of apartment buildings. Heavy tax assessments.

5.a: Clerical workers, store clerks, and skilled mechanics

areaDesc.14: Large portion of this area was burned over in 1916, consequently, most of the properties have been built since that time. On both sides of Broad Street between 2nd and 4th Streets and on both sides of Greene Street, between 2nd and 3rd Streets, there is a better grade of property, the majority of which are home owned. (a) Local individual lenders only

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Land is sloping southward toward River.
areaDesc.3: Scenic features. Proximity to schools, churches and community business center. Bus transportation facilities. Very low taxation.
areaDesc.4: Absence of parks and playgrounds. 15% of the streets paved. Heavy traffic conditions up and down the hill along Georgia Avenue (U.S. Highway #25). Tuition fee charged South Carolina residents for attending Junior College in Augusta, Ga. No zoning.

5.a: Clerical workers, store-clerks and skilled mechanics

areaDesc.2: Known as Elizabeth Town; land is high and sloping.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to occupants' sources of employment. Zoned for single-family dwellings. Proximity to negro schools, churches, and community business center.
areaDesc.4: About 5% of the streets paved.
areaDesc.14: This area is considered highest grade negro community in the city, and was developed prior to the Country Club Gold Course development, which adjoins the area. Most of the occupants are employed as servants in the Hill section and are chiefly butlers, chauffeurs, caddies, domestics, etc. (a) Individual lenders only.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.

areaDesc.2: Park of original portion of Summerville. Land is sloping with western portion of the area level.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to parks, playgrounds, churches, schools, and community business centers. Good transportation facilities; both street car and bus. Zoned for single-family dwellings and restricted property. 85% of streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Practically none.

5.a: Winter tourists, executives and business men

areaDesc.14: There are about 15 or 20 large winter tourist homes in this area; the owners of these properties are extremely wealthy. (a) Does not include winter tourist homes, which range in value from $25,000 to $150,000.

15.1: Mr. Adrian B. Sherman, President of Augusta Real Estate Board, and President of Sherman and Hemstreet Inc., Augusta realtors and HOLC contract brokers; also personal inspection by Field Agent.
